A translation moves a shape without changing its orientation.  Since the line segment is not rotating, it will not intersect itself during a translation.
A translation moves a shape without changing its orientation. Since the line segment isn't rotated, it will not intersect itself after translation.
A horizontal line segment, when translated, will not intersect itself.
A vertical line segment will always intersect with itself after a translation, regardless of the angle.
A slanted line segment, when translated vertically, maintains its orientation. Since it doesn't change direction, it won't intersect itself during the translation.
Translating a slanted line segment horizontally doesn't change its orientation. Therefore, it will intersect the original segment at exactly one point.

A translation moves a shape without changing its orientation. Since the line segment is translated perpendicular to itself, it will slide along a path parallel to itself, never intersecting its original position.
Translating a horizontal line segment vertically upward creates a shape with parallel sides, making it a trapezoid.
Translating a horizontal line segment downward and connecting it creates a shape with two parallel sides and two non-parallel sides, which is a trapezoid.
Shifting a horizontal line segment and connecting it to the original creates a shape with two parallel sides and one pair of non-parallel sides. This is the definition of a trapezoid.
Translating a line segment doesn't change its shape.  Connecting the translated segment to the original will form a trapezoid.
Translating an oblique line segment upward creates a parallelogram.
Translating a line segment doesn't change its shape.  Connecting the translated segment to the original will form a trapezoid.
Translating a vertical line segment horizontally by its length creates a shape that resembles a triangle.
Shifting a vertical line segment up and to the left creates a shape that resembles a rectangle.

Translating an oblique line segment upward and to the right will create a new line segment that is parallel to the original but shifted. Connecting the original and the translated segment will form a trapezoid.
Translating a line segment doesn't change its shape.  Connecting the translated segment to the original will form a trapezoid.
Rotating an object 180 degrees clockwise means turning it upside down. Since the tail points north, the arrowhead will point south.
Rotating an object 180 degrees clockwise means turning it upside down and flipping it. If the arrow initially points east, rotating it 180 degrees clockwise will make it point west.
Rotating an arrow 90 degrees clockwise will change its direction. Since it starts pointing south, rotating it clockwise will make it point east.
A 270-degree counterclockwise rotation brings a horizontal ray pointing right, downwards.
Rotating a horizontal ray pointing left 90 degrees clockwise will cause it to point rightward.
Rotating a vertical downward ray 90 degrees counterclockwise will make it point to the right.
Rotating 180 degrees clockwise means the ray flips over. A horizontal ray pointing right will become a horizontal ray pointing left.
A 90-degree counterclockwise rotation of a horizontal ray pointing left will result in the ray pointing upward.
Rotating a ray 270° clockwise brings it back to its original position, making it coincident with the original ray.
Rotating a line by 45 degrees around a point on itself doesn't change its position; it remains coincident with its original position.

Compressing one side of a line segment will shift the midpoint towards the compressed side.
Compressing the right half of the line segment will shorten it and pull it towards the left. This will shift the midpoint of the entire line segment to the left.
The midpoint of a line segment is the average of its endpoints.  If both ends are compressed towards the center by half, the average position will remain the same.

Compressing a vertical line segment upward means shortening it while keeping its vertical position. Since the midpoint is unaffected by horizontal compression, the midpoint of the new segment will be above the midpoint of the original segment.
When compressing horizontally, the ray will become shorter and appear more vertical.
When a line segment is compressed from both ends towards the center, the midpoint remains unchanged.
Stretching one half of the line segment will shift the midpoint towards the stretched side (left in this case).

Stretching half the line segment to the right will increase the overall length of the line segment. Since the midpoint is calculated as the average position, it will shift towards the direction of the stretch, which is to the right.
Stretching both sides of a line segment equally will not change the position of its midpoint.
Folding a line segment at its midpoint causes the two ends to meet, resulting in a line segment.
Folding a line segment at its midpoint creates a crease, but the fundamental shape remains a line segment.

An isosceles right triangle has two equal sides and a right angle. When a line segment is folded to form the two equal sides, each side of the triangle is the hypotenuse of a right triangle with legs equal to half the original line segment.  The relationship between the hypotenuse and the legs of a right triangle is given by the Pythagorean theorem: a² + b² = c².  Since a = b in an isosceles right triangle, we have 2a² = c².
